utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: I make weird noises. Hi, I'm Greg Gutfeld with Katie Pavlich, Geraldo Rivera, Jesse Watters and evil Shannon Bream. THE FIVE. President Biden begging Democrats to save his rear end before jetting off to Europe to see the Pope. Joe telling Dems behind closed doors to either pass his massive spending plan or his presidency is toast. He then announced that his party has reached the framework on a $1.75 trillion deal that he says will transform America.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: Any single element of this framework would fundamentally view -- be viewed as a fundamental change in America. Taken together, they're truly consequential. When paired with the bipartisan infrastructure bill, we will truly transform this nation. As I said before, these plans are fiscally responsible. They're fully paid for. They don't add a single penny to the deficit. I want everybody to be able to -- if they want to be a millionaire or billionaire to be able to seek their goal, but all I'm asking is, pay your fair share.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Okay. But so far radical Democrats say almost $2 trillion doesn't go far enough and they're threatening to blow up Biden's big plans.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: So you're not on board with this framework because it's not drafted?

utterances.speaker: SEN. BERNIE SANDERS (I-VT)
utterances.sentences: I want to see the language. I want to see it improve.

utterances.speaker: HALLIE JACKSON, MSNBC HOST
utterances.sentences: You are a no if Nancy Pelosi were to bring up this infrastructure vote in the next day or so, next couple of days?

utterances.speaker: REP. CORI BUSH (D-MO)
utterances.sentences: If it's by itself, if it's a stand-alone, absolutely. I'm 100 percent a no. There is no getting me to a yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Progressives have also been clamoring to see text of the bill. Pelosi just dropped the 2,400 pages worth. So bust out your reading glasses, Jesse, old man. As has for when a vote actually happens, Nancy Pelosi is being crystal clear.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Are you holding an infrastructure vote today? Have you made that decision? So are you holding an infrastructure vote today? Are you holding an infrastructure --

utterances.speaker: REP. NANCY PELOSI (D-CA)
utterances.sentences: No, I'm just getting my mask.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: A true leader. So Jesse, there is a Democrat victory in here. They have made it so Americans see 1.75 as a small number because they began --

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: A bargain.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- yes, $3 trillion, which means their strategy actually worked and we're screwed. That's --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, we're screwed. I don't think the strategy worked. I think it was a total mess. And I hope I'm wrong, but I do think they're going to get something passed within the next five days so they give Joe a win overseas so he can beat his chest to the world and they got to get something done under the wire before that election on Tuesday, too. So, the media is now going to write this story. This is the comeback kid. And that's just going to be an inside the beltway story though because for the rest of the American people, this two-headed monster of a bill is not going to affect them in a positive way especially in the short term. It does nothing for the border or inflation. It does nothing for the supply chain and does not create jobs. If anything, the Democrats are going to own inflation when they're spending trillions on top of what we already have right now. They already own the border crisis and they're slipping in this bill, I did read some of it, Greg. Amnesty for 10 million illegal immigrants. They are going to own high gas prices because they slipped in a little green new deal here. And they're going to own the weak recovery because they're going to raise taxes higher than it's ever been done before. In a couple years you may have government-run day care in a couple once they get that off the ground, but in the near term private day care is going to skyrocket because they're going to have to compete with this new program. And then what, maybe in one year they're going to have a few electric car charging stations, great. Only two percent of us own an electric vehicle so that's not really that great. Some of the spending is good. You know, you want Wi-Fi and nice railroads and less traffic, but a lot of this is just doubling down on the boondoggle of bankrupt programs like Medicaid and Medicare which aren't really doing that well right now. So, this country's going to sit around what, for the next couple days and watch a bunch of untalented politicians bad at arithmetic try to raise taxes so they can square the numbers to see if they can pay for stuff that no one wants or needs. That's basically what we're watching right now.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. Kudos to your assistant for reading that stuff and then boiling it down to a paper for you to read.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. But here's the thing, Shannon. He may know some of the facts, but at 2,400 pages, we never know. We keep repeating the same mistake. That's the worst part about this. We know that most of this is crap in there, but no one reads it because it's impossible. That's the big lie, is that we actually know what's going on.

utterances.speaker: SHANNON BREAM, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: Well, and the thing is, I know that you think maybe it's a foregone conclusion they get something done, we literally just got an e-mail from Jason Donner one of our very intrepid Capitol Hill producers who just talked to Manchin who said we're working together in good faith, moving forward.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.sentences: We're hearing the same thing from Senator Sinema. You've got a lot of folks over in the House. It looks like the Speaker is not ready to pull the trigger on this infrastructure vote because they don't seem like they're actually convinced and all on board either. So, I think what the president came out and said today is like we've made progress but I don't think we've seen a press release from anyone saying we have a deal.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.sentences: So I think in D.C. there's still a lot of steps to go here. They got to think, too, they're trying to sneak in, as you said this stuff about immigration. The parliamentarian has ruled against them on this and they've acknowledged that. Senator Dick Durbin, one of the top Democrats said we know but we're going to try again. So they know that they're kind of throwing everything at the wall so they can say they've got to win, but big things that people expected and wanted in like Democrats have run for years on lowering prescription drug prices, it looks like now that's not going to be a part of the bill. A lot of things that people said we got to have it or we're not going to do it, that's in there. And, you know, we played in the opening the president did his interesting whisper thing where he says pay your fair share three times.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.sentences: Pay you fair share. Pay your fair share. Well, according to the IRS, a non-partisan group, the top five percent of income earners pay 60 percent of income taxes so, that's up to the American people where they think that's enough.

utterances.speaker: GUTGELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. That's all they rely on, is that phrase, pay your fair share. It's not going to work anymore because people have the internet. They know what people are paying. Geraldo, he went to visit the Pope. What do you think of the Pope? You know him don't you? You hang out. You had dinner with him on the (inaudible), the pope.

utterances.speaker: GERALDO RIVERA, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: I like the Pope. I'm half Catholic so I could hang out with him --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: There's no such thing.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: -- half a day.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Half a lick (ph).

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: No, I am -- I am half Catholic and half Jewish, but I feel fully Catholic and fully Jewish. So, if you can't get your mind around that then you don't understand your colleague. You know what disappoints me the most here is how the progressives and the squad have been revealed as, you know, part -- petty politicians who would not allow an infrastructure bill to go forward where they would be the, you know, the bridges repaired and the streets and the, you know, and the Wi-Fi. I mean, they could have done so graciously, yes, we want this big bill, the other bill to remake society and all the rest and be very generous to the least amongst us, but let's do this for everybody where everybody benefits. A highway that's smooth without holes in it, it benefits the rich and the poor alike. And the fact that they were against it and they used their power to screw Pelosi and force her into this unwieldy bill I think is really disappointing to me because I have been a huge fan of their energy, of their new insights, you know, and that their idealism, but they are revealed to be rather than idealistic. They're revealed to be politicians, ruthless politicians of a different sort.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I can't believe that they are ruthless politicians. Oh my god. Anyway, Katie, I go to you last because I want you to help me.

utterances.speaker: KATIE PAVLICH, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUITOR
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm an LWH. I'm a libertarian without hope.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Okay. Fair enough.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I feel that we've gone to this place where you have people are going to be relieved to have a $2 trillion dollar bill that's 2,500 pages and that means -- that means essentially anybody who believes in small government it's over, it's dead well.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm going to give you some hope. I know you'll reject it because you're a libertarian without hope, but I will give you some of it. If you look at the polling on this reconciliation package in every state that's run by, you know, Democrats but also Republicans, purple states West Virginia for example, Arizona, people are against this kind of spending. And so even if they pass it and get it shoved down their throats, they're going to look at it next year maybe in 2024 and say we watched what you did, we didn't want it and you voted for it anyway depending on how these votes go down. Now, someone's going to have to blink here. It's either going to have to be Senator Sinema and Senator Manchin or these socialists, I will not call them progressive, socialists in the House who are holding this up because a deal was made this summer on infrastructure between Republicans and Democrats at the White House. The president promised they would not go together to be voted on. They're changing that now. It was interesting to watch Nancy Pelosi come out today kind of exacerbated saying I'm releasing the text so you can complain about it which is pretty funny. So, we'll see what they can do but Joe Biden's on the verge of being a lame duck president. He doesn't have much time to get anything done. And at this point, he can't get infrastructure done and he can't get the reconciliation package done and therefore he has nothing to show the first year in his presidency, which does not give him a lot of strength in negotiating power moving forward.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know who he should talk to? Hunter, the smartest man he's ever met.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Smartest man he's ever met.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Where did you -- where do you get that 10 million illegal aliens getting amnesty?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's in the bill.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Did you make that up?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I read it in the text.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: You did not.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. Not this text, but the pretext.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: It was in the framework.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: The pretext.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's in the framework.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: It's a pretext.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's in the framework.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.sentences: It's like backdating to 1979 for some of the status.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: What do you mean by it?

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.sentences: Well, backdating some of the status for people who came here earlier than you're currently available --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Oh, I see.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Amnesty.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: You're talking about dreamers.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The word is amnesty.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Dreamers.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Control yourself people.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: I mean you portrayed them so evilly.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Coming up, disgraced former New York Governor Andrew Cuomo just got charged with a sex crime. The breaking news, next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: This is a Fox News alert. Disgraced former New York Governor Andrew Cuomo has been charged with a sex crime. According to the complaint, the incident took place last December and says Cuomo forcibly touched an intimate body part under a woman's shirt, but did not name the victim. It comes just two months after Cuomo resigned in disgrace when 11 women came forward to accuse him of sexual misconduct. And "The New York Post" reporting it's expected that Cuomo will be arrested next week. So, Geraldo, this is a misdemeanor charge, forcible touching. Tell us what you know.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Well, let me read quickly the statue. A person is guilty of forcible touching when such person intentionally and for no legitimate purpose forcefully touches the sexual or other intimate parts of another person for the purpose of degrading or abusing such person or for the purpose of gratifying the actor's sexual desire or misdemeanor punishable by up to a year in prison. More importantly, he would have to register as a sex offender, what he purportedly did. Remember the state trooper?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: The female state trooper. He put his hand allegedly under her blouse and touched her belly. So, you know, I don't know if there were any witnesses. I think it's a he said she said, but in the climate of today, you know, when she says people believe. And so I think that he's screwed if I can misuse a verb there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Katie Pavlich, your thoughts.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Well, it's not just that he said she said at this point because they clearly believe they have enough proof to take it to a court of law. So, that's a little bit different than having this argument and debate in the media versus him actually being charged for a crime he will have to register as a sex offender. I'm wondering if his brother, Chris Cuomo, who helped develop these statements, who actually was editing and approving statements going after these women on official government time for New York. He would write something or approve something that then showed up on the New York governor's website published as a press relief -- release, what he has to say about this now that it's reached criminal charges. So whether this will go through, you know, he's supposed to appear in court next week, whether he'll plead guilty or not is still a question, but we certainly moved from just allegations and reports from the attorney general of these types of things taking place into the arena of prosecutors obviously believe that they have enough to prove this or they wouldn't take it to a court of law.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And if he is convicted, do you think forcible touching misdemeanor conviction, do you think he actually would serve prison time?

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.sentences: I doubt it. He's going to be looked at. The court will look at him as a first-time offender.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.sentences: Now if these cases pile up and other women come together and there are additional charges that could change for him. But I think most of us would agree as a first-time offender probably not and being the governor, but there are a lot of folks who said listen, New York State officials, lawmakers, have dropped the ball like they stopped the impeachment thing because as you've said he was going to resign. But there are a lot of people who are saying, listen, if he's facing criminal charges maybe they do that just to assure he cannot run again. So I think there are all kinds of calculations here, but what an amazing turnaround from a year ago. You think about that he -- it was rumored he was going to be the attorney general nominee for that. He could run for president. He got a huge book advance for the book "American Crisis: Leadership Lessons from the COVID-19 Pandemic." By the way, I just looked it up on Amazon, its 196,306th ranked. Yours is way ahead of that, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I would hope so.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.sentences: But listen, to think of what happened in the last year to where he's now facing criminal charges for touching a woman's body against her wishes and there are multiple potential cases out there, this is far from over for him.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Greg Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. I would say it's a fall from grace, but there was never any grace to fall from. He went from Hollywood's favorite sexiest governor to an unemployed accused sex offender. So he might actually have a future in Hollywood. And thank god Chris is still at CNN, his brother, because then he won't have to cover it. But it raises the question what happens over at CNN with Chris Cuomo because he was advising his brother, we get it. He was telling him about how to smear the accusers. He was in and all the calls, but right now you're seeing CNN's numbers in a death spiral, in a free fall. They have never been in a situation like this before. And it's safe to say that there's a combination of factors contributing to this and this is one of them. That women are turning off CNN because of their support for Andrew Cuomo. I believe that with all my heart. It's a disgrace. I think they should shut down the network.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Do you have any siblings? Just curious.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I have three older sisters.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: And it -- would they not advise you if you got into jail?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: A little different.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.sentences: If

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: I think it's a little different --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Let me tell you something.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: -- because he's public, but advising Greg --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They've been advising Greg --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I think we've been -- I think we've been through that, our argument. And it's beyond that now. The guy has, I mean, Cuomo works at CNN. You don't advise a public figure, a governor, if you're that. You have to step down from something or step out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well he won't be covering it tonight on the show --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Of course not.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- or any night on the show.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I will be covering like --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: But no one will know because no one watches that network.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- climate change. Climate change. He'll be covering that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's urgent.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Another ratings bonanza. Coming up, the battle over education ramps up. Wait until you hear the latest attack on concerned parents.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.sentences: Upset parents being called all sorts of names in the battle over education. Democratic Virginia gubernatorial candidate Terry McAuliffe making another controversial claim.

utterances.speaker: TERRY MCAULIFFE, DEMOCRATIC VIRGINIA GUBERNATORIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: I am sick of them talking about these issues of critical race theory. We do not teach critical race theory here in Virginia. It has never been taught. It is a racist dog whistle. It is pitting parents against parents, parents against teachers, and they're using our children as political pawns and it has got to stop.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.sentences: So, while McAuliffe denies that CRT is being taught in schools, take a look at these headlines. Virginia's department of education promoting a book that says "teachers must embrace theories such as critical race theory." A slide presentation from Fairfax County public schools reportedly instructed social studies teachers that "critical race theory is a frame for their work." And Christopher Rufo who has been leading the way on this issue says Terry McAuliffe just not telling the truth.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUFO, CONSERVATIVE ACTIVIST
utterances.sentences: McAuliffe's idea that it's not taught in Virginia schools is verifiably false. We have records including actual contract receipts from Loudoun County, Virginia. They actually are paying $625 an hour for consulting that specifically references critical race theory by name.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.sentences: All right. Katie, this is turning out to be a huge deal where we live in Virginia and the governor's race is underway. I mean, whether Terry McAuliffe wants it to be or not it is.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Terry McAuliffe keeps insulting the very people he needs to vote for him, the people who've ten thousand of them have taken their kids out of out of schools in Loudoun County alone, Fairfax County. The fact is that they are teaching critical race theory. He doesn't want to acknowledge it, but telling people it's just not happening, you know, makes them feel pretty insulted. Fairfax County paid Ibram X. Kendi who is a racist himself $20,000 to give a speech for an hour to school administrators and to teachers last summer. They backed that up when it came to light in public documents that they had paid that much money, saying it was essential to how they learned to teach children. It's not just the issue of critical race theory either. It's about pornographic books being in these libraries for young children. Parents reading them out loud and embarrassing school boards over it and they (inaudible). What do you think the parents are doing? They're -- Terry McAuliffe also keeps smearing parents by saying this is a racist dog whistle to bring up critical race theory. There are parents in Loudoun County, in Fairfax County from all different backgrounds including a woman who grew up in Mao's China who have come up to these meetings to say we don't want this in our schools. It is not just white parents who are living in suburbia going to these school board meetings. And finally I would say it is not a good look for the Loudoun County school board to be calling the sheriff's department and acting like these people are domestic terrorists asking for all these insane security measures simply to keep them out from speaking to them when they are taxpayer- funded. They have the right to be there. And so, you know, Terry McAuliffe thinks that insulting them is the way out of this when he should really be listening to them and their concerns.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.sentences: Well, he does need their votes. Whoever's going to win there has got to get those votes. Now, I thought this was interesting. In Minnesota, there's a school board that says if you're going to come up and speak you have to list your name. You have to say it out loud, your name and your address or Jesse, you won't be allowed to speak.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. So they're basically asking parents to dox themselves.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Wow. That's pretty scary and it's uncalled for. There's no need for that, but McAuliffe, I don't know if he's dumb or lying or doesn't know what CRT is. He gave birth to CRT in 2015. It started in Virginia under his tutelage, Shannon Bream. And now it's taken off like a rocket ship. Katie's right. They have all kinds of contracts for all kinds of wackos and institutions, one of whom got $2.4 million and that happened to be the son- in-law of Merrick Garland. And it's not just that. I've read all the texts in the language in that commonwealth of Virginia. It's talking about white students need to apologize and acknowledge their white privilege. It makes black students ashamed of their heritage. It's really sick stuff. They are teaching racism in Virginia and if parents oppose that the governor says you're a racist. That's where we are in 2021. But I think the wheels have fallen off the McAuliffe campaign. He seems defensive. No one's showing up to his events. And now he's just criticizing voters that he needs to get.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Twenty bucks he wins.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Do you think 20?

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.sentences: Are you going to take it?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Listen, this is a blue state that Biden won by double digits and now it's a dead heat because of this issue.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: A win is a win, 20 bucks.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Hey, 20.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.sentences: Are you going to take it right here?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Twenty?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Twenty.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Let's go.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.sentences: Shaking on it. Okay.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Let's go.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.sentences: Next week we're going to check back in on that. Okay, in the meantime, Geraldo, parents do have a lot of different concerns. Katie talked about this and there's a big ad that has to do with this about books and things that are full of vulgarity and violence that when they've gone to read them before the school board, the school boards were like, you can't use that language here, like actually shut them down. But parents say, listen, we should know what's involved with our kids and we should have a say.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Well, true, all true. But for decades I've heard this argument about, you know, it was always about sex in the old day. You know, don't teach, you know, a word or explicit sex to the kids, they are too young. I think that, I want to be a moderate here. I think both sides are right. I think it -- and I also think that everybody is now on notice. Everybody is on noticed. The teachers unions, after getting burnt and the national school board association, all the -- after getting burnt in these embarrassing headlines about uh you know lying about what they -- what they're doing, what their instincts are, what their, you know, critical race there is, I think that they, on the one hand, get it. And on the other hand, the parents -- and Katie, I think you're almost always right except when I look at the school board meetings, I see a sea of white faces. Nothing --

utterances.speaker: KATIE PAVLICH, FOX NEWS CHANNEL CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: Well, you're not looking very hard.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: There's nothing wrong with that --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: You're not looking very hard then. You pay be more attention

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Well, maybe I'm missing -- maybe I'm missing the odd Puerto Rican here or there, but I just don't --

utterances.speaker: SHANNON BREAM, FOX NEWS CHANNEL ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: But they are there are other American parents that are showing it too.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: But I think -- what my point is that I think that the parents are on notice that egregious over aggressive, that -- is over the top. And I think that teachers are also on the notice.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: You were never overly aggressive, Geraldo.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: You were never overly aggressive

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.sentences: Not me.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.sentences: Well, Greg, apparently, some yelling and screaming is OK, but other yelling and screaming and burning things down, OK not OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

So, this idea that this is clean energy just isn't true. President Biden begging Democrats to save his rear end before jetting off to Europe to see the Pope. Joe telling Dems behind closed doors to either pass his massive spending plan or his presidency is toast. He then announced that his party has reached the framework on a $1.75 trillion deal that he says will transform America.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.utterance: Any single element of this framework would fundamentally view -- be viewed as a fundamental change in America. Taken together, they're truly consequential. When paired with the bipartisan infrastructure bill, we will truly transform this nation. As I said before, these plans are fiscally responsible. They're fully paid for. They don't add a single penny to the deficit. I want everybody to be able to -- if they want to be a millionaire or billionaire to be able to seek their goal, but all I'm asking is, pay your fair share.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Okay. But so far radical Democrats say almost $2 trillion doesn't go far enough and they're threatening to blow up Biden's big plans.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.utterance: So you're not on board with this framework because it's not drafted?

utterances.speaker: SEN. BERNIE SANDERS (I-VT)
utterances.utterance: I want to see the language. I want to see it improve.

utterances.speaker: HALLIE JACKSON, MSNBC HOST
utterances.utterance: You are a no if Nancy Pelosi were to bring up this infrastructure vote in the next day or so, next couple of days?

utterances.speaker: REP. CORI BUSH (D-MO)
utterances.utterance: If it's by itself, if it's a stand-alone, absolutely. I'm 100 percent a no. There is no getting me to a yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Progressives have also been clamoring to see text of the bill. Pelosi just dropped the 2,400 pages worth. So bust out your reading glasses, Jesse, old man. As has for when a vote actually happens, Nancy Pelosi is being crystal clear.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.utterance: Are you holding an infrastructure vote today? Have you made that decision? So are you holding an infrastructure vote today? Are you holding an infrastructure --

utterances.speaker: REP. NANCY PELOSI (D-CA)
utterances.utterance: No, I'm just getting my mask.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A true leader. So Jesse, there is a Democrat victory in here. They have made it so Americans see 1.75 as a small number because they began --

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: A bargain.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- yes, $3 trillion, which means their strategy actually worked and we're screwed. That's --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, we're screwed. I don't think the strategy worked. I think it was a total mess. And I hope I'm wrong, but I do think they're going to get something passed within the next five days so they give Joe a win overseas so he can beat his chest to the world and they got to get something done under the wire before that election on Tuesday, too. So, the media is now going to write this story. This is the comeback kid. And that's just going to be an inside the beltway story though because for the rest of the American people, this two-headed monster of a bill is not going to affect them in a positive way especially in the short term. It does nothing for the border or inflation. It does nothing for the supply chain and does not create jobs. If anything, the Democrats are going to own inflation when they're spending trillions on top of what we already have right now. They already own the border crisis and they're slipping in this bill, I did read some of it, Greg. Amnesty for 10 million illegal immigrants. They are going to own high gas prices because they slipped in a little green new deal here. And they're going to own the weak recovery because they're going to raise taxes higher than it's ever been done before. In a couple years you may have government-run day care in a couple once they get that off the ground, but in the near term private day care is going to skyrocket because they're going to have to compete with this new program. And then what, maybe in one year they're going to have a few electric car charging stations, great. Only two percent of us own an electric vehicle so that's not really that great. Some of the spending is good. You know, you want Wi-Fi and nice railroads and less traffic, but a lot of this is just doubling down on the boondoggle of bankrupt programs like Medicaid and Medicare which aren't really doing that well right now. So, this country's going to sit around what, for the next couple days and watch a bunch of untalented politicians bad at arithmetic try to raise taxes so they can square the numbers to see if they can pay for stuff that no one wants or needs. That's basically what we're watching right now.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. Kudos to your assistant for reading that stuff and then boiling it down to a paper for you to read.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. But here's the thing, Shannon. He may know some of the facts, but at 2,400 pages, we never know. We keep repeating the same mistake. That's the worst part about this. We know that most of this is crap in there, but no one reads it because it's impossible. That's the big lie, is that we actually know what's going on.

utterances.speaker: SHANNON BREAM, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: Well, and the thing is, I know that you think maybe it's a foregone conclusion they get something done, we literally just got an e-mail from Jason Donner one of our very intrepid Capitol Hill producers who just talked to Manchin who said we're working together in good faith, moving forward.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: We're hearing the same thing from Senator Sinema. You've got a lot of folks over in the House. It looks like the Speaker is not ready to pull the trigger on this infrastructure vote because they don't seem like they're actually convinced and all on board either. So, I think what the president came out and said today is like we've made progress but I don't think we've seen a press release from anyone saying we have a deal.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: So I think in D.C. there's still a lot of steps to go here. They got to think, too, they're trying to sneak in, as you said this stuff about immigration. The parliamentarian has ruled against them on this and they've acknowledged that. Senator Dick Durbin, one of the top Democrats said we know but we're going to try again. So they know that they're kind of throwing everything at the wall so they can say they've got to win, but big things that people expected and wanted in like Democrats have run for years on lowering prescription drug prices, it looks like now that's not going to be a part of the bill. A lot of things that people said we got to have it or we're not going to do it, that's in there. And, you know, we played in the opening the president did his interesting whisper thing where he says pay your fair share three times.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Pay you fair share. Pay your fair share. Well, according to the IRS, a non-partisan group, the top five percent of income earners pay 60 percent of income taxes so, that's up to the American people where they think that's enough.

utterances.speaker: GUTGELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. That's all they rely on, is that phrase, pay your fair share. It's not going to work anymore because people have the internet. They know what people are paying. Geraldo, he went to visit the Pope. What do you think of the Pope? You know him don't you? You hang out. You had dinner with him on the (inaudible), the pope.

utterances.speaker: GERALDO RIVERA, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: I like the Pope. I'm half Catholic so I could hang out with him --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There's no such thing.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: -- half a day.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Half a lick (ph).

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: No, I am -- I am half Catholic and half Jewish, but I feel fully Catholic and fully Jewish. So, if you can't get your mind around that then you don't understand your colleague. You know what disappoints me the most here is how the progressives and the squad have been revealed as, you know, part -- petty politicians who would not allow an infrastructure bill to go forward where they would be the, you know, the bridges repaired and the streets and the, you know, and the Wi-Fi. I mean, they could have done so graciously, yes, we want this big bill, the other bill to remake society and all the rest and be very generous to the least amongst us, but let's do this for everybody where everybody benefits. A highway that's smooth without holes in it, it benefits the rich and the poor alike. And the fact that they were against it and they used their power to screw Pelosi and force her into this unwieldy bill I think is really disappointing to me because I have been a huge fan of their energy, of their new insights, you know, and that their idealism, but they are revealed to be rather than idealistic. They're revealed to be politicians, ruthless politicians of a different sort.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I can't believe that they are ruthless politicians. Oh my god. Anyway, Katie, I go to you last because I want you to help me.

utterances.speaker: KATIE PAVLICH, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUITOR
utterances.utterance: Okay.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm an LWH. I'm a libertarian without hope.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Okay. Fair enough.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I feel that we've gone to this place where you have people are going to be relieved to have a $2 trillion dollar bill that's 2,500 pages and that means -- that means essentially anybody who believes in small government it's over, it's dead well.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Well, I'm going to give you some hope. I know you'll reject it because you're a libertarian without hope, but I will give you some of it. If you look at the polling on this reconciliation package in every state that's run by, you know, Democrats but also Republicans, purple states West Virginia for example, Arizona, people are against this kind of spending. And so even if they pass it and get it shoved down their throats, they're going to look at it next year maybe in 2024 and say we watched what you did, we didn't want it and you voted for it anyway depending on how these votes go down. Now, someone's going to have to blink here. It's either going to have to be Senator Sinema and Senator Manchin or these socialists, I will not call them progressive, socialists in the House who are holding this up because a deal was made this summer on infrastructure between Republicans and Democrats at the White House. The president promised they would not go together to be voted on. They're changing that now. It was interesting to watch Nancy Pelosi come out today kind of exacerbated saying I'm releasing the text so you can complain about it which is pretty funny. So, we'll see what they can do but Joe Biden's on the verge of being a lame duck president. He doesn't have much time to get anything done. And at this point, he can't get infrastructure done and he can't get the reconciliation package done and therefore he has nothing to show the first year in his presidency, which does not give him a lot of strength in negotiating power moving forward.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know who he should talk to? Hunter, the smartest man he's ever met.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Smartest man he's ever met.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Where did you -- where do you get that 10 million illegal aliens getting amnesty?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's in the bill.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Did you make that up?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I read it in the text.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You did not.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. Not this text, but the pretext.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: It was in the framework.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: The pretext.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's in the framework.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: It's a pretext.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's in the framework.

utterances.speaker: BREAM

utterances.utterance: Oh, I see.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Amnesty.

utterances.utterance: You're talking about dreamers.

utterances.utterance: The word is amnesty.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Control yourself people.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I mean you portrayed them so evilly.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Coming up, disgraced former New York Governor Andrew Cuomo just got charged with a sex crime. The breaking news, next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This is a Fox News alert. Disgraced former New York Governor Andrew Cuomo has been charged with a sex crime. According to the complaint, the incident took place last December and says Cuomo forcibly touched an intimate body part under a woman's shirt, but did not name the victim. It comes just two months after Cuomo resigned in disgrace when 11 women came forward to accuse him of sexual misconduct. And "The New York Post" reporting it's expected that Cuomo will be arrested next week. So, Geraldo, this is a misdemeanor charge, forcible touching. Tell us what you know.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Well, let me read quickly the statue. A person is guilty of forcible touching when such person intentionally and for no legitimate purpose forcefully touches the sexual or other intimate parts of another person for the purpose of degrading or abusing such person or for the purpose of gratifying the actor's sexual desire or misdemeanor punishable by up to a year in prison. More importantly, he would have to register as a sex offender, what he purportedly did. Remember the state trooper?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: The female state trooper. He put his hand allegedly under her blouse and touched her belly. So, you know, I don't know if there were any witnesses. I think it's a he said she said, but in the climate of today, you know, when she says people believe. And so I think that he's screwed if I can misuse a verb there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Katie Pavlich, your thoughts.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Well, it's not just that he said she said at this point because they clearly believe they have enough proof to take it to a court of law. So, that's a little bit different than having this argument and debate in the media versus him actually being charged for a crime he will have to register as a sex offender. I'm wondering if his brother, Chris Cuomo, who helped develop these statements, who actually was editing and approving statements going after these women on official government time for New York. He would write something or approve something that then showed up on the New York governor's website published as a press relief -- release, what he has to say about this now that it's reached criminal charges. So whether this will go through, you know, he's supposed to appear in court next week, whether he'll plead guilty or not is still a question, but we certainly moved from just allegations and reports from the attorney general of these types of things taking place into the arena of prosecutors obviously believe that they have enough to prove this or they wouldn't take it to a court of law.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And if he is convicted, do you think forcible touching misdemeanor conviction, do you think he actually would serve prison time?

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: I doubt it. He's going to be looked at. The court will look at him as a first-time offender.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Now if these cases pile up and other women come together and there are additional charges that could change for him. But I think most of us would agree as a first-time offender probably not and being the governor, but there are a lot of folks who said listen, New York State officials, lawmakers, have dropped the ball like they stopped the impeachment thing because as you've said he was going to resign. But there are a lot of people who are saying, listen, if he's facing criminal charges maybe they do that just to assure he cannot run again. So I think there are all kinds of calculations here, but what an amazing turnaround from a year ago. You think about that he -- it was rumored he was going to be the attorney general nominee for that. He could run for president. He got a huge book advance for the book "American Crisis: Leadership Lessons from the COVID-19 Pandemic." By the way, I just looked it up on Amazon, its 196,306th ranked. Yours is way ahead of that, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I would hope so.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: But listen, to think of what happened in the last year to where he's now facing criminal charges for touching a woman's body against her wishes and there are multiple potential cases out there, this is far from over for him.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Greg Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. I would say it's a fall from grace, but there was never any grace to fall from. He went from Hollywood's favorite sexiest governor to an unemployed accused sex offender. So he might actually have a future in Hollywood. And thank god Chris is still at CNN, his brother, because then he won't have to cover it. But it raises the question what happens over at CNN with Chris Cuomo because he was advising his brother, we get it. He was telling him about how to smear the accusers. He was in and all the calls, but right now you're seeing CNN's numbers in a death spiral, in a free fall. They have never been in a situation like this before. And it's safe to say that there's a combination of factors contributing to this and this is one of them. That women are turning off CNN because of their support for Andrew Cuomo. I believe that with all my heart. It's a disgrace. I think they should shut down the network.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Do you have any siblings? Just curious.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I have three older sisters.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: A little different.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: If

utterances.utterance: Let me tell you something.

utterances.utterance: -- because he's public, but advising Greg --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They've been advising Greg --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think we've been -- I think we've been through that, our argument. And it's beyond that now. The guy has, I mean, Cuomo works at CNN. You don't advise a public figure, a governor, if you're that. You have to step down from something or step out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well he won't be covering it tonight on the show --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Of course not.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- or any night on the show.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I will be covering like --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But no one will know because no one watches that network.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- climate change. Climate change. He'll be covering that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's urgent.

utterances.utterance: I am sick of them talking about these issues of critical race theory. We do not teach critical race theory here in Virginia. It has never been taught. utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: So, while McAuliffe denies that CRT is being taught in schools, take a look at these headlines. Virginia's department of education promoting a book that says "teachers must embrace theories such as critical race theory." A slide presentation from Fairfax County public schools reportedly instructed social studies teachers that "critical race theory is a frame for their work." And Christopher Rufo who has been leading the way on this issue says Terry McAuliffe just not telling the truth.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUFO, CONSERVATIVE ACTIVIST
utterances.utterance: McAuliffe's idea that it's not taught in Virginia schools is verifiably false. We have records including actual contract receipts from Loudoun County, Virginia. They actually are paying $625 an hour for consulting that specifically references critical race theory by name.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: All right. Katie, this is turning out to be a huge deal where we live in Virginia and the governor's race is underway. I mean, whether Terry McAuliffe wants it to be or not it is.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Terry McAuliffe keeps insulting the very people he needs to vote for him, the people who've ten thousand of them have taken their kids out of out of schools in Loudoun County alone, Fairfax County. The fact is that they are teaching critical race theory. He doesn't want to acknowledge it, but telling people it's just not happening, you know, makes them feel pretty insulted. Fairfax County paid Ibram X. Kendi who is a racist himself $20,000 to give a speech for an hour to school administrators and to teachers last summer. They backed that up when it came to light in public documents that they had paid that much money, saying it was essential to how they learned to teach children. It's not just the issue of critical race theory either. It's about pornographic books being in these libraries for young children. Parents reading them out loud and embarrassing school boards over it and they (inaudible). What do you think the parents are doing? They're -- Terry McAuliffe also keeps smearing parents by saying this is a racist dog whistle to bring up critical race theory. There are parents in Loudoun County, in Fairfax County from all different backgrounds including a woman who grew up in Mao's China who have come up to these meetings to say we don't want this in our schools. It is not just white parents who are living in suburbia going to these school board meetings. And finally I would say it is not a good look for the Loudoun County school board to be calling the sheriff's department and acting like these people are domestic terrorists asking for all these insane security measures simply to keep them out from speaking to them when they are taxpayer- funded. They have the right to be there. And so, you know, Terry McAuliffe thinks that insulting them is the way out of this when he should really be listening to them and their concerns.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Well, he does need their votes. Whoever's going to win there has got to get those votes. Now, I thought this was interesting. In Minnesota, there's a school board that says if you're going to come up and speak you have to list your name. You have to say it out loud, your name and your address or Jesse, you won't be allowed to speak.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. So they're basically asking parents to dox themselves.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wow. That's pretty scary and it's uncalled for. There's no need for that, but McAuliffe, I don't know if he's dumb or lying or doesn't know what CRT is. He gave birth to CRT in 2015. It started in Virginia under his tutelage, Shannon Bream. And now it's taken off like a rocket ship. Katie's right. They have all kinds of contracts for all kinds of wackos and institutions, one of whom got $2.4 million and that happened to be the son- in-law of Merrick Garland. And it's not just that. I've read all the texts in the language in that commonwealth of Virginia. It's talking about white students need to apologize and acknowledge their white privilege. It makes black students ashamed of their heritage. It's really sick stuff. They are teaching racism in Virginia and if parents oppose that the governor says you're a racist. That's where we are in 2021. But I think the wheels have fallen off the McAuliffe campaign. He seems defensive. No one's showing up to his events. And now he's just criticizing voters that he needs to get.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Twenty bucks he wins.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do you think 20?

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Are you going to take it?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Listen, this is a blue state that Biden won by double digits and now it's a dead heat because of this issue.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: A win is a win, 20 bucks.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Hey, 20.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Are you going to take it right here?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Twenty?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Twenty.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Let's go.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Shaking on it. Okay.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Let's go.

utterances.utterance: Next week we're going to check back in on that. Okay, in the meantime, Geraldo, parents do have a lot of different concerns. Katie talked about this and there's a big ad that has to do with this about books and things that are full of vulgarity and violence that when they've gone to read them before the school board, the school boards were like, you can't use that language here, like actually shut them down. But parents say, listen, we should know what's involved with our kids and we should have a say.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Well, true, all true. But for decades I've heard this argument about, you know, it was always about sex in the old day. You know, don't teach, you know, a word or explicit sex to the kids, they are too young. I think that, I want to be a moderate here. I think both sides are right. I think it -- and I also think that everybody is now on notice. Everybody is on noticed. The teachers unions, after getting burnt and the national school board association, all the -- after getting burnt in these embarrassing headlines about uh you know lying about what they -- what they're doing, what their instincts are, what their, you know, critical race there is, I think that they, on the one hand, get it. And on the other hand, the parents -- and Katie, I think you're almost always right except when I look at the school board meetings, I see a sea of white faces. Nothing --

utterances.speaker: KATIE PAVLICH, FOX NEWS CHANNEL CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: Well, you're not looking very hard.

utterances.utterance: There's nothing wrong with that --
