utterances.utterance: Well, maybe I'm missing -- maybe I'm missing the odd Puerto Rican here or there, but I just don't --

utterances.speaker: SHANNON BREAM, FOX NEWS CHANNEL ANCHOR
utterances.utterance: But they are there are other American parents that are showing it too.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: But I think -- what my point is that I think that the parents are on notice that egregious over aggressive, that -- is over the top. And I think that teachers are also on the notice.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: You were never overly aggressive, Geraldo.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: You were never overly aggressive

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Not me.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Well, Greg, apparently, some yelling and screaming is OK, but other yelling and screaming and burning things down, OK not OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, in fact, you know, McAuliffe called it a dog whistle, the parents concern. There are actual real racist dog whistles. If you think black people can't get an I.D., that's a -- that's a dog whistle. If you think rioting and looting is acceptable behavior because they're Black, that is a racist dog whistle. I used to think there's nothing more racist than a low bar, but the Dems introduced no bar. And that's what we're seeing right now. That's why there were so few prosecutions after all of these riots. Look, to them, the left, everything is racist except actual racism. You can blanket all whites as oppressive, and that's not racism, that's considered education. But if you call it out, McAuliffe calls you a racist. But I think -- well, I think it was your point, Jesse. I can't remember. I think it's over. Generally, it's over. They have killed the accusation of racism once and for all. You keep calling people racist, it doesn't mean anything anymore. They beat it to death. And people are not afraid -- people used to be afraid of being called racist because it is. It's like being called a pedophile. But they did it so much, it's like, you know what, I'm going to challenge you, I am not a racist. And that's what parents are doing. I think -- I think the left is in trouble. If they don't come up with new ideas, they're sunk.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Well --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: See? Now, I'm a hopeful libertarian.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: That didn't sound very hopeful to me.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: In a blink of an eye, you guys have brought him up. All right, coming up, the United Nations dropping a bizarre climate change video featuring a dinosaur.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: The United Nations going from the prehistoric to the ridiculous with their new video on climate change. Check it out. It features a talking dinosaur addressing the general assembly and warning those big bad humans about global warming.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: I know a thing or two about extinction. Going extinct is a bad thing. At least we had an asteroid. What's your excuse. You're headed for a climate disaster, and yet every year governments spend hundreds of billions of public funds on fossil fuel subsidies.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You know, Jack -- is that Jack Black? Does that sounded like Jack Black to you? Anyway, isn't the problem that the -- I was in LA when I first moved to LA 20 years before you were born, I remember the skies were brown.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: OK. Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: It was horrible, if you were on one of the first freeways. And I was -- in '99 -- '98, I was in Beijing with Clinton and again, it was chocolate skies. So you can't deny that humans are affecting in a negative way the climate.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I mean, isn't the real issue that the United States can't do it alone, that we can't sacrifice or pay for what China is not going to do, what India is not going to do?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Well, I would say LA now does not have the same skies that you experience Beijing --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: It's true.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: -- however does, which proves that a free market system in the United States capitalist system can get rid of pollution which is very different than trying to control the climate through just pumping money into a global system. This is not about climate change in the environment at all. It's about government control. So, thousands of everyday products are made with petroleum. If you control the energy, you control everything else. So, you control how people can heat their homes, you control what they get to buy. And that's exactly what this globalist governance wants at the U.N. Apparently, they have enough money to make stupid videos that have nothing to do with actual real solutions to solving --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's our money.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's our money. And so, it's not about clean energy because they call it clean energy like these electric cars and buses that the president touted today. They're actually really terrible for the environment. Those batteries, you have to mine them in China. You have to use a ton of water to get them out of the earth, and then you can't really dispose of them. The same thing goes for solar panels and wind turbines. So, this idea that this is clean energy just isn't true. It's just a mechanism to control money, and as Greg just pointed out, to get more of it from Americans to give it to Europeans and the rest of the world.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I think that's a very grim assessment of solar power and wind power.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Well, it's true.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: And kids love dinosaurs, so there's nothing wrong with using that gimmick is there, Jesse? Wouldn't your twins pay attention to that?

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, FOX NEWS CHANNEL HOST
utterances.utterance: Well, Geraldo, this is not for kids, is it? I mean, is this for kids or is this for adults? This looks like it's for adults at the UN, so think about that for a second.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's Democrats which are children.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, it's for children a.k.a. Democrats. You're right. Katie is right. This is not about the science. The science changes anyway depending on whoever you give the grant money to. This is about give me your money right away or you're going to die. That's a stick-up job, Geraldo. That's what this is about, constraining American capitalism, and for liberals to feel relevant and virtuous to throw other people's money at a problem, a problem that you can't even keep track of. Since 1986, emissions went up in this country and then in 2007 shale revolution, Geraldo, natural gas, and our emissions are down back to the 86 levels while India and China are exploding their emission.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: So you are -- you are hopeful?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, why are we paying other counties to pollute?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Should we not be concerned?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We have amazing clean air clean water. We preserve the natural --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I don't know. In Michigan, they make this group that clean waters.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- resources of this country. It's not a very densely populated country, Geraldo. You drive around this country, you don't see people for miles. It's a nice clean country.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Plenty of room for those illegal aliens.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Which we're going to pay a half a million for separating them from their moms. I'll take a half a mil if you break me up with my mom.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Oh, she's going to text you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'll throw her something.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: That's right. That's right. You like John Kerry, the climate ambassador? Is he making a difference?

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Well, OK, but here's the thing I thought was so funny. And when we started talking about John Kerry today, I thought a few weeks ago, he was over in China. He says that his whole lifestyle is about traveling the world to stop the fossil fuels and the use of them. He was in China a few weeks ago and while he was there, because we got to go and have these conversations, he had virtual meetings with leaders and he could have just done that from the United States.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What? No.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Yes, he was having virtual meetings after he had traveled all the way over there. So, I think maybe there is some room for improvement on his carbon emission situation.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: But having a high-profile guy in charge of it or person in charge of it.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Well, I don't know, him, the dinosaur, I don't know. By the way, the dinosaur to me was a clever idea when you're talking about extinction. He did sound sort of like he had a southern accent.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Well, it was Jack Black.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: I mean, like, was he discovered in Alabama. And where's his mask?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: My grandkids loved them, but to Jesse's point this was not supposed to be for the -- for the children. Crunchy Critters, do you know -- you know what that is? They're now advocating the harvesting of insects. And they said, if we eat insects, that will improve the environment.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And the people that are pushing that don't do it except for Brianna Keilar on CNN. Do you remember when she stuffed --

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Cicadas.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: She did? She ate a crunchy critter?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. And talking dinosaur I thought looked great. I mean, the botox has really helped Kerry's fossilized face.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Greg.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Oh, no.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: If this -- stop it. He deserves it.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: He's a war hero.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: If this were a Republican ad, if this were a Republican ad, CNN would do a fact check, right? There's no proof that dinosaurs could speak the queen's English. This is absolutely absurd. But we are often told how harmful things are, like words, costumes, right? The Halloween costumes, we're being told, you know, don't wear -- no cap guns, no cinema blood, and then there's certain words that are triggers, they're considered traumatic, and yet you can have -- the left can have a dinosaur tell you that life is ending. And it is actually appealing to children to use the dinosaur. So, scaring people for some reason is only the turf of really comfortable rich white liberals in their electric cars.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Well, you know who's not going to be convinced. It's China.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Well, all I know is that Tesla just sold, what was it, 100,000 vehicles to Hertz. So, somebody disagrees with you. "THE FASTEST" is up next.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Welcome back. Time for "THE FASTEST." First up, 30 of Americans say they're not afraid to live in a haunted house if it means that they'll score a dream property. So, is anyone about THE FIVE down for this? Greg, would you live in a haunted house?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What if your dream house is a haunted house? I would love a truly haunted house because that means there's stuff out there that we don't know about. I'd love to hear weird noises at night if it were ghosts and not like weirdo homeless people peeing in my front yard.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: So, Geraldo, the survey also found that 20 percent of Americans wouldn't mind living in a house where a murder took place.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Based on your experience, did you meet any of these people?

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: What do you mean your experience?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I'm from long island. I went to high school there. The Amityville horror house is a real place. And I get the itchies. I don't like it. I'd rather have bad -- a good juju than bad juju. And why invite bad juju?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: There were like --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You anti-Semite.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: It's only good juju.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Listen, you know, I'm sleeping with the Bible next to me on the nightstand. So, if the bad guys come in, we're going to have a problem. Just don't -- like you said, just don't wake me up. Like, I'm not really that scared of stuff, but I'm like, if you bother my sleeping, we're going to have a problem.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Isn't that funny you sleep with the Bible and Dagen sleeps with a loaded gun?

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Well, listen. I live in Virginia so you can have both of those.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: You can have both on your bedside. So Jesse, almost a third of Americans believe that they have already lived in a haunted house.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. I mean, I'd put up with a ghost for a penthouse on park avenue for sure. I mean, what's the worst that could happen, Geraldo? I'm possessed?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: It depends -- it depends on the ghost.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right. We call the exorcist, right, and then he's done.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's true. OK, up next, a new study claims men are just as emotional as women and even weep more than their female counterparts on average about four times a month. Guys apparently become emotional while watching sports. To our sports fan.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Have you seen the eagles this season?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You've cried.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I cried every Sunday.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: How much have you cried?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, I don't cry.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Ever?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I mean, I don't cry a lot. I've cried maybe once in the last couple of years.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Really?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So, Geraldo --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: When Jesse Jr. was born.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Oh, that's nice. That's a nice time to cry if you're going to unleash it -- unleash it that one time.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Geraldo, you're maybe not a crier but you're definitely emotional.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I am emotional. You know --- but when I get mad at Greg, say, it's over in a heartbeat. I get mad and then it's over.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because I'm adorable.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You know -- and I do -- when I cry -- I cry at like Lassie movies, you know, like a happy ending when the handicapped person walks. You know, it's -- I am that mercurial person. But I think that that's why I'm doing OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, you're feeling great.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: So, Greg, I don't know -- I don't know if I believe this study necessarily but I do think that men cry more when they get a cold or they're sick.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, maybe. But the thing is if this -- if this study actually found the truth that there are actually dramatic differences, it would have been buried because sex difference research doesn't exist anymore. In fact, I doubt that they will be doing this research because it deals with two binary sexes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Are you saying men and women are different?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, my goodness.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I know. That's why --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: That's it. That's it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- the only -- the only research --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: We're off air.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The only research that you see now is that we're all indifferent. We're all the same.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know if that's the same. But -- and that's the truth.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Shannon, your thoughts about women versus men in crying.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Well, I really think it's more of an age thing. Like, the older I get -- both my husband and I are like more tender-hearted.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes, I think that's true.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Every time we show a homecoming video of a soldier reuniting with their kids or whatever, like I'm just -- I can't do the rest of the show. I think it's more of an age thing.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I think that's true. All right, and finally, more proof sibling rivalries never go away. One in two adults say they still argue and compete with their brothers and sisters into adulthood over issues like career goals and even homeownership. Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's very hard. I have three older sisters. It's very hard for me because I'm the famous one. And I remind them constantly that I'm the most famous sibling given the fact that when I was growing up, they constantly teased me and bothered me, made my life a living hell. And now, I can lower my fame over them.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Are they -- are they on the payroll? Are they on the payroll?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No. I don't put my family on the payroll unless they want to.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wait, not everybody does that, Geraldo.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I was at Scotto's at the bar and I was talking with a guy who was very accomplished and I said, what else do you have to accomplish? He told me all his achievements. He said, now I have to outlive my sister.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I hope my sister is not competing with me because that would be sad. She's getting crushed.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Shannon?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You're going to get a mom text.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Really.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Five, four, three, two --

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Several of them, several. I'm -- I am my siblings biggest fans. And by the way, my brother just got promoted to lieutenant colonel. So, we cheer for each other.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's true.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I want to apologize --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's so Shannon.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I want to apologize to my sister. I didn't really mean that.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, you're evil. You're evil and yore trying to cloak it in being nice.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: And you can't take it back.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Jesse --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's not like she's watching Fox. Are you crazy? She's never seen the show.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I will say that if my brother starts competing with me, I'll be in trouble because he's a very smart engineer. All right, "ONE MORE THING" up next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There you go. All right, time now for "ONE MORE THING." I'm going to go first. Look at this. These are brand new. They're available in the Fox Shop.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: It doesn't have a horn.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh yes, I know. That's true. We'll make one for you. There -- they are only -- guess how much these this is.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Are they made in America?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They're made -- $25.00.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Definitely made in America.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So, if you go to foxnews.com, you can buy yours today. They'll probably be sold out in a matter of minutes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You'll get a piece?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You'll get a piece?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Good question.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Are you kidding?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: His sisters get it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, I don't --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Let's do this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Animals are great! Animals are great! Animals are great!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, you know, you can't do that. You can't do that. There's other stuff on my website too, GGutfeld. That's where I get a piece. All right, check out this cat. I don't like cats, but I like this cat. Look, there's - - that's called a coyote.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: That's a coyote.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right, a coyote walking around, and here comes the cat.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Oh, good cat.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That is a hero cat.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I like that cat.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Loot at him. Look at that speed.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I have coyotes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. That was -- it's Phoenix cat named Sonny. And it was all caught on surveillance. That's it for me. Cats are great. Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Friendly neighborhood dispute update. We got the poll results in. I told you about a situation. A cop just started ticketing everybody. We were within earshot. He says, guys, can you move your cars? No, handing out tickets like candy, all right. First up, LMH911 says no. Just because he can doesn't mean he should. He should have the decency to speak to the people parked there. That's what builds community. Exactly. Michael Shoemaker says if you're parked illegally, then you are parked illegally. I would be fuming mad, but this dude was literally doing his job. Jesse said he knows the manager and the manager over that manager. He's totally being a Karen about the subject.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I agree.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Oh, Karen.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Whatever, Michael. RowdyLil says no, not if the people are within earshot. Come on, man.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: RowdyLil. She sounds like fine.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And finaly, PoppaNoz says yes, suck it up, Jesse. You broke the law and now you're whining. You sound like Omar.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Omar and Karen.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Drumroll, please. And the results are in. I win. 67 percent said the cop was totally out of line. He should not have just ticketed everybody. He should have given us a heads up.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: That was (INAUDIBLE). Sham poll.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Is it rigged? Is it rigged?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Totally rigged. Here is tonight's edition of G1eraldo news with Geraldo. Check out Cops all access on Fox Nation. It's a great show. It's really happening. They just renewed it until the spring. People are piling on it's a -- Cops is great. It's been around forever. The thin blue line is our people. We love them. In other Geraldo news with Geraldo. Remember, I have a charity. I'm honored to be a part of Life's Work. We've opened 50 group homes over the last 50 years since I did the stories about the institution -- institutions. This is the Geraldo home, the first one of the 50 that we opened. That looked a little stagey there. But Eric Adams, the probable next mayor of New York, said some nasty things about the handicap being dumped because of overreaction to exposes. He did it without educating himself. He went to the Geraldo Home over the weekend. He saw with his own eyes how humane treatment of these people. And Katie, I'm sorry, I didn't take your time.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Well, it's Shannon's turn.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: Well, that's beautiful. You are making a real difference. OK, just very cute because we need a little bit of happiness. Senator Tom Tillis had his bipartisan dog costume parade in Capitol Hill for their staffers and their little doggies. An event where lawmakers can actually be nice, get together, have some fun, and cuties.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Who won the costume contest?

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: I don't know. I'm trying to figure out what these little guys are dressed up as.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Katie, you got 10 seconds.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Luke Bryan helps a nice lady named Courtney Potts. He changed her tire on the side of the road.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.utterance: I love it.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Nice surprise for her.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Luke Bryan did?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's very nice. All right, that's it for us.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: (INAUDIBLE)

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: "SPECIAL REPORT" up next. Hello, Bret!
